In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

You can define the function `audi_filter` as follows:

```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter for manufacturer "Audi" and models "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    filtered_df = df_cars[df_cars["manufacturer"] .== "Audi", :]
                                          , ["model"]
                                          .== Union["a4", "a4 quattro"]]
                                          ]

    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` with all values as `true`
    filtered_df[!, :audi_a4_
assistanttype"] .= true

    return filtered_df
end
```

You can now call this function using your DataFrame `df_cars`:

```julia
result_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

The variable `result_df` will contain the filtered DataFrame as per your requirements.
